headline: COMCAST HAS LOSS IN ACQUISITIONS AND UPGRADE COSTS
summary: The Comcast Corporation, the cable-television operator seeking to buy AT&T's broadband unit, had a third-quarter loss on acquisition and upgrade costs as sales and cash flow beat analyst estimates. The loss was $106.8 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with net income of $1.25 billion, or $1.29, a year earlier, the company said. The Philadelphia-based company offered to buy New York-based AT&T's cable unit, the nation's largest, for stock and assumed debt now valued at $51.2 billion. AT&T rejected the bid in July. Comcast's operating cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, rose 17 percent to $705.8 million from $605.7 million. The company was expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call, to report $680.4 million in cash flow.

headline: It's Not Silly Season? Just Read This
summary: IS it just me, or has the Garden State somehow crossed over into its own private Twilight Zone? Suddenly we seem to have gone from being just occasionally weird to being everyday weird. Maybe the now-fading aura of Halloween week has something to do with it, but I suspect it's more than that. I suspect that strangeness is the new status quo. I don't mean the paranoia related to current events, unsettling as they are. I'm talking about a paradigm shift in the rules of life itself -- bizarre, unexplainable meltdowns in the order of the universe. Witness, for instance, the fact that I just used the phrase ''paradigm shift'' even though I have no idea what it means!

headline: AT&T Is Sticking to Timetable on Cable Unit
summary: C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, reiterated yesterday that he hoped to decide on a plan to either spin off or sell the company's cable television unit by the end of the year. AT&T Broadband is the No. 1 cable television company in the United States.

headline: Incredibly Shrinking AT&T And the Armstrong Agenda
summary: C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, has sympathizers in high places these days. The way Mr. Armstrong tells it, he was stepping down from a panel discussion in Manhattan on Monday when another panelist put an arm around him and drew him aside.

headline: Johnson and Longley Hurting Bottom Line
summary: Larry Johnson and Luc Longley are gone from the Knicks' roster, but clearly not forgotten by their former employers at Cablevision. There will be no corporate tributes to Johnson, who retired, and Longley, who was waived. There will be no statues erected in their honor outside Madison Square Garden, a division of Cablevision.

headline: AOL-AT&T Cable Talks Said to Be Advancing
summary: AOL Time Warner's tentative discussions about acquiring the cable television business of AT&T have edged forward, with AOL Time Warner signing a confidentiality agreement that could allow the talks to move to a new stage, people close to the negotiations said. Executives from AOL Time Warner began speaking with their AT&T counterparts about a cable deal over the summer. But after the Sept. 11 attacks, the talks were relegated to a back burner.

headline: Creditors' Move Puts Excite@Home's Service at Risk
summary: A judge will be asked on Friday to rule that Excite@Home can cut off Internet access to its 3.7 million subscribers, who are caught in a battle over the bankrupt company's assets and future. The request is being made by creditors of Excite@Home, who are owed hundreds of millions of dollars. They hope that the threat of a shutdown will extract more money from the other parties in the dispute.

headline: Excite@Home Wins Ruling About Cable
summary: A federal judge ruled today that Excite@Home, the bankrupt provider of high-speed Internet access, could sever its contracts with the cable companies that offer its service, meaning that about 3.7 million subscribers in North America could lose Internet access as early as this weekend. After the ruling, however, Excite, its creditors and the cable companies said they were in negotiations to prevent an imminent service interruption, and people close to the talks said they thought a settlement could be reached.

headline: Internet Provider Cuts Off 850,000 AT&T Customers
summary: Excite@Home, the bankrupt provider of high-speed Internet access, cut off Internet service to 850,000 AT&T customers yesterday after AT&T refused to meet its demands -- said to be for more than $100 million -- to continue the service. As of Friday night, AT&T, which is hastily building its own network, balked at making this payment, according to an executive familiar with the talks. Excite@Home cut off AT&T's Internet customers shortly after midnight.

headline: GOING OUT
summary: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com. Music BLAIR ACADEMY Tom Chapin Today at 4 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 for those 62-plus; $10 for students. DuBois Theater, Blairtown. (908) 362-6121, extension 5612.

headline: Excite Said to Reach Pact To Keep Internet Service On
summary: Excite@Home reached a tentative agreement yesterday with a group of cable companies, including Cox Communications and the Comcast Corporation, to keep their customers connected to Excite's high-speed Internet service, according to several people involved in the negotiations. But not all of the creditors of Excite, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, have decided whether to support the agreement. That means it may not be clear for days whether 2.7 million people in North America will have their cable Internet service cut off.

headline: Suitors Line Up to Compete For Cable TV Unit at AT&T
summary: The story of AT&T's cable television unit begins a new chapter this evening, when bids are due from competing suitors for the unit, the nation's largest cable operation. AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications, which are each already among the nation's biggest cable companies, are all expected to submit formal bids. Microsoft, meanwhile, is expected to propose acquiring a minority stake, as it looks toward winning a captive market for its own software products.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Enron Seeks Bankruptcy And Takes Dynegy to Court Enron filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, but sought to remain in business with the support of its creditors. The company also said it sued Dynegy for billions of dollars in damages for withdrawing its buyout offer. [Page A1.] Steve Jobs Rejects Microsoft Plan Apple Computer's chairman and chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, says that Microsoft's proposal to settle antitrust lawsuits would allow it to dig into the education market, one of the few Microsoft does not dominate. Microsoft has proposed giving away $1 billion in software, hardware and expertise to the nation's poorest schools to end 100 class-action lawsuits. [C3.]

headline: Cable Companies Sign On For Excite@Home Service
summary: Excite@Home signed an agreement yesterday afternoon with a group of cable companies, including the Comcast Corporation and Cox Communications, to maintain high-speed Internet access for their customers. The deal, which the companies have been working on since Friday, will provide approximately $355 million to tide Excite over for the next three months, while the two major companies create replacement networks. Of that figure, Cox and Comcast will each pay $160 million.

headline: Market Place; Three giants square off in the bidding for the biggest cable prize of all, AT&T Broadband.
summary: THREE of the nation's biggest cable companies lined up yesterday in hopes of taking over the largest one, AT&T Broadband, submitting complex bids that AT&T will begin reviewing in the coming days. And Microsoft, which is already a minority stakeholder in AT&T, has indicated that it will financially support competing bids for AT&T Broadband from both the Comcast Corporation and Cox Communications in an effort to keep it out of the hands of AOL Time Warner.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Auto Sales Remain Strong As Incentives Are Reduced Auto sales remained strong for much of November but slowed after Thanksgiving, when automakers started to restrict their interest-free financing offers. The pace of auto sales dropped to an annual selling rate of 18 million vehicles in November, down from 21.3 million in October, but up 9.5 percent from last November, according to Ward's AutoInfoBankData. Year-end projections are for 17 million vehicles, just behind last year's record. [Page C4.]

headline: For Cable-Modem Customers, a Switch Causes a Scramble
summary: PHONE company or cable company? Just when it seems as though a clear winner is emerging in the race to offer the most exasperating Internet service, the other pulls ahead. The latest leg seems to have been won by the cable companies, at least those offering service from Excite@Home, a bankrupt provider of high-speed Internet access.

headline: AOL TIME WARNER GETS A NEW CHIEF AS LEVIN DEPARTS
summary: The chief executive of the world's biggest media company, AOL Time Warner, surprised his company and his industry yesterday by announcing that he would retire in May. The executive, Gerald M. Levin, will be replaced by his hand-picked successor, Richard D. Parsons, who will face the daunting job of making a merger conceived in the soaring Internet economy come of age during an economic slump for old-line and online media companies alike. News of the handoff comes less than a year after America Online acquired Time Warner in a $165 billion deal that was supposed to have created a behemoth capable of exploiting the growth of the Internet while remaining a powerhouse in film, television and magazines.

headline: AOL's Future Chief to Bring Washington Connections
summary: Richard D. Parsons, the newly designated AOL Time Warner chief executive, has forged a reputation for being a politically gifted and gracefully diplomatic corporate advocate with exceptional Republican contacts. For AOL Time Warner this is no small thing. Washington is expected to be an important battlefield for the company in the coming months, on a range of issues that include cable television ownership limits, cable and broadcasting cross-ownership limits, and Internet access rules, among others. Mr. Parsons's contacts and persuasive charms will be important weapons in the AOL Time Warner arsenal, people inside and outside of the company say.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 More Violence Jolts Efforts To Quell Mideast Conflict Four Palestinian police officers were shot dead by Israeli troops and another Palestinian suicide bombing wounded several Israelis, further jolting efforts to arrange a cease-fire. A6

headline: AT&T Finds Cable TV Bids Unacceptable
summary: AT&T has reviewed the three competing bids for its cable television business, the nation's largest, and found all of them inadequate. AT&T's chairman conveyed that message to the bidders -- AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications -- on Saturday evening, after its board spent the day considering the bids. Although the board is hoping that the response may elicit one or more sweetened offers, people close to the deliberations said, it is beginning to seem that AT&T is once again leaning toward a spinoff of its cable business into an independent company.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Clears Excite@Home Plan
summary: The At Home Corporation may continue to provide cable companies with high-speed Internet service under a $355 million agreement, a judge ruled after the companies waived some claims against each other. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Thomas Carlson approved the settlement, saying At Home has gained something very valuable.'' The contracts with Cox Communications Inc., the Comcast Corporation and other cable companies will give At Home financing to continue operating through the end of February, when it plans to cease operations.

headline: AT&T IS SAID TO BE REQUESTING NEW BIDS FOR CABLE UNIT
summary: AT&T has asked the three companies that are vying to acquire its cable television business to submit new proposals by Sunday morning, people close to the talks said yesterday. AT&T's board is set to weigh the offers on Wednesday and could make a final decision on the cable unit's fate at that meeting, the people said. AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications have each submitted bids to acquire the unit. At a meeting last weekend, AT&T's board deemed each of those offers inadequate. Financial details have not been disclosed, but any sale would be worth at least $40 billion. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

headline: AT&T Weighs Cable Unit Sale as Bids Are Revised
summary: Bidders in the auction for AT&T's cable television business submitted revised offers late yesterday in a last-ditch effort to persuade AT&T's board to sell the operation. AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications submitted reworked offers, according to executives involved in the auction, after an admonishment last week from AT&T's chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, that the bids were inadequate.

headline: Technology & Media; For Some Dot-Coms, There Are Real Profits
summary: Meet Brad D. Greenspan and at first it seems like he's a visitor from another era -- the Internet bubble of 1999. He's a 28-year-old chief executive of a public Internet company, eUniverse, with tens of millions of users and big backers like Sony.

headline: AT&T's Board To Meet Today On Cable Sale Or a Spinoff
summary: Amid a late push by AOL Time Warner, AT&T's board is to meet in Manhattan today to decide whether to sell the company's cable television operation or instead spin it off as an independent company. AOL Time Warner, Comcast and Cox Communications have each submitted bids to acquire AT&T's cable business, the nation's biggest.

headline: A Bright Spot in a Bleak Holiday Retailing Season
summary: In the worst year in recent memory for most retailers, there appears to be one small bright spot: the Internet. Many of the biggest store chains, other than the discounters like Wal-Mart, are bracing for sales to be lower than last year. But Internet sales, while growing more slowly than in past years, are expected to increase by about 30 percent, according to recent surveys. While the frenzy of the last few years has come to a halt, millions of new people are still signing up for Internet service every year. And the online stores that have weathered the Internet industry shakeout have solved many of the technology and warehouse problems that bedeviled online shoppers in years past.

headline: Philadelphians Take a Giant Step Toward Leading the U.S. Cable Industry
summary: For years, the Roberts family of Philadelphia has been determined to expand Comcast, its midranked cable company, into an industry giant. In 1999, that strategy suffered a big setback at the hands of AT&T, which beat out Comcast in a bidding war for another major cable operator, MediaOne. So when a stumbling AT&T announced plans last year to spin off its cable properties, Brian Roberts, Comcast's president, saw a chance to get even and big at the same time. Comcast's $44.5 billion hostile bid in July put AT&T Broadband into play, and now has put the business into the Roberts's hands, turning Comcast into the nation's No. 1 cable operator.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: AT&T to Sell Cable Unit To Comcast for $47 Billion AT&T agreed to sell its cable television business, the nation's largest, to Comcast for $47 billion in stock. The deal would create a cable giant with more than 22 million subscribers, almost twice the size of the next-biggest cable operator, AOL Time Warner, which was a losing bidder for the operation. [Page A1.] No Deal on Stimulus Package Congress gave up hope of reaching a deal this year with the Bush administration on an economic stimulus package. [A1.]

headline: COMCAST WINS BID FOR AT&T'S CABLE
summary: AT&T agreed yesterday to sell its cable television business, the nation's largest, to the Comcast Corporation for about $47 billion in stock. The deal would create a cable giant with more than 22 million subscribers, almost twice the size of the next-biggest cable operator, AOL Time Warner, which was a losing bidder in the deal.

headline: Clash of the Convergers
summary: Comcast won the auction for AT&T's cable television business yesterday, but the other big winner was Microsoft. Using its deep pockets, Microsoft gave financial support to the Comcast bid and thus played the spoiler in denying the prize to its archrival, AOL Time Warner. Most of the nation's 70 million cable television subscribers may wonder why so much corporate emotion and money were involved in the fight over AT&T's cable business. To most people, a cable network is merely a way of delivering garden-variety television and collecting monthly bills.

headline: New Era in Washington Paves Way for This and Other Deals
summary: Beyond its business rationale, the proposed merger of the nation's largest and third-biggest cable television companies announced tonight reflects the sea change in the regulatory thinking of Washington policy makers. A series of favorable court decisions this year and the appointment by President Bush of senior regulators skeptical of the old rules have ushered in a new era of deregulation in telecommunications. As a result, the proposed deal between AT&T and Comcast, which would have been unthinkable only a year ago, is not expected to encounter any serious impediments here.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
summary: INTERNATIONAL A3-22 Argentine Leader Declares State of Siege Amid Looting President Fernando de la RÃºa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across the country. The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas in several cities, and four people were killed. The disturbances appeared to be a mix of spontaneous pilferage by unemployed workers and organized protests by government opponents. A3 New Terms for Colombia Aid The House attached a series of conditions to aid to Colombia, demanding that the government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence there. The Senate, which initiated the restrictions, is expected to concur. A19

headline: How the Comcast Deal Came Together
summary: Brian Roberts's first instinct was to try to trump Rupert Murdoch. More than a year ago, Mr. Roberts, the president of Comcast, was anxiously watching Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation maneuver for control of the DirecTV service. That would have given Mr. Murdoch the access he craved into American living rooms, creating the most formidable enemy yet for the cable industry. But over a lunch at Lindy's deli across from Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, another idea was planted in Mr. Roberts's head.

headline: Expect More Mergers, Experts Say, at Expense of Consumers
summary: Investors may benefit more than consumers from the pending combination of the cable operations of AT&T and Comcast. The creation of AT&T Comcast, a cable behemoth with 22 million subscribers, is likely to set off a new round of mergers in the cable industry, analysts said -- deals that can be expected to pay investors a premium.

headline: For AOL, Goals Are Deferred, Not Denied
summary: In losing its bid for AT&T Broadband, AOL Time Warner may have failed to instantly become the dominant cable force that it might have. But even though the AT&T unit will be combined with Comcast and have significant backing from AOL's rival, Microsoft, AOL's main objectives are likely to be deferred rather than denied. For AOL, AT&T's 13.8 million cable subscribers represented important potential customers for its cable networks, like CNN, and high-speed versions of its America Online.

headline: Who Has What and Will Vote What
summary: For each of their shares, holders of AT&T stock will receive .34 share, or about $13.07, in the new AT&T Comcast. Comcast holders will simply be reissued shares in the new company. AT&T has said that its shareholders would own 56 percent of AT&T Comcast, but the full picture of the combined company's ownership is a bit more complex, mostly because of a complicated investment by Microsoft in AT&T.

headline: Corrections
summary: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Comcast Corporation's acquisition of AT&T Broadband misspelled part of the name of AT&T's law firm. It is Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz; not Wachtel.

headline: The AT&T Chief's Report Card
summary: In 1998, just two days after AT&T announced its great leap into the cable television business, C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman, was already exasperated. ''The disinformation, it's incredible,'' he said in an interview barely 48 hours after the company had announced a $31.8 billion deal to acquire Tele-Communications Inc. ''I've never seen anything like it.''

headline: A Clash of Online Titans
summary: AT&T's sale of its cable television business, the nation's largest, to Comcast, the third-largest, is more than another episode in the continuing consolidation of the nation's cable industry. The bidding war for AT&T Broadband must also be seen as another skirmish in the conflict between Microsoft and AOL Time Warner to control the information pipes that bring news, entertainment and communications services into American households. If federal regulators approve this cable merger, as seems likely, they must impose conditions aimed at preserving and fostering competition in the online world. Microsoft owns a stake in Comcast, though it does not directly operate cable systems itself. But with cable companies' digital or ''broadband'' pipelines ideally positioned to distribute high-speed Internet access, interactive TV and perhaps even local phone service, Microsoft clearly wants to ensure its access to cable. It wants to expand its own Internet service provider and build as dominant a franchise in the market for cable operating software as it has for personal computers.

headline: In Cable, The Race Approaches A Far Turn
summary: COMCAST'S planned $47 billion acquisition of AT&T Broadband is the latest, biggest step toward consolidation in the cable industry. But it is probably not the last. Most American households have access to cable. Yet many people apparently do not want the service, because the number of paying customers is rising very slowly. Companies are building better systems, spending a lot of money. Hence the need for size.

headline: THE DEAL OF THE YEAR
summary: Ending almost a year of wrangling, brinksmanship and high-stakes negotiations, Comcast struck a deal to acquire AT&T's cable television unit. The final price: $47 billion in stock. Comcast was already the nation's No. 3 cable operator. After ingesting AT&T's cable operation, AT&T Comcast will be a behemoth with more than 22 million customers, or roughly one of every five homes in the United States. Seth Schiesel

headline: Demand Grows For Net Service At High Speed
summary: It has been a tumultuous year for providers of high-speed Internet service. Three companies that offer it over phone lines filed for bankruptcy. So did the leading provider of high-speed Internet service over cable TV systems, Excite@Home. And the largest cable company, AT&T Broadband, spent much of the year trying to decide its future before finally falling into the arms of Comcast last week. While each of these events had some effect on customers, nothing has deterred an increasing number of Americans from signing up for high-speed -- or broadband -- Internet access.

headline: AT&T SELLS OFF WIRELESS STAKE FOR $1.4 BILLION
summary: AT&T, which is selling assets to reduce debt, sold its remaining stake in its former wireless unit for $1.4 billion. AT&T had retained a $3 billion stake in AT&T Wireless Services, the third-largest mobile-phone company in the nation, which was spun off in July. AT&T had already reduced the stake by $1.6 billion. Last week, AT&T agreed to sell its cable business to Comcast for $72 billion. AT&T's debt rose to $65 billion last year after it spent over $100 billion to form the biggest cable operator in the nation. The company has said it planned to have debt of $35 billion, after subtracting cash, at the end of the year.

headline: Small Cable Operators Worry About Life After Big Mergers
summary: The stakes in the battle for the nation's televisions are gargantuan -- subscription TV generates revenue of $60 billion a year. So the players need to be gargantuan as well, some industry executives argue. Thus the big are getting bigger in order to prepare for a clash of the titans. The two big satellite television companies, EchoStar Communications and DirecTV, are trying to consolidate to create a single company with nearly 17 million subscribers. At the same time, the Comcast Corporation has agreed to buy the cable television unit of AT&T, a move that would make it the largest cable company with more than 22 million subscribers.

headline: In Rewritten Internet Fables, The Late Bird Gets the Worm
summary: On Sunday, Dec. 16, with little disruption, a small Internet company called iWon began operating the remains of the Web portal Excite.com. IWon picked up Excite -- which was valued at $6.7 billion just three years ago -- at the fire-sale price of under $10 million as part of the messy bankruptcy of Excite@Home, the company that developed the Excite portal. It was the latest sign that the Internet has entered a reconstruction phase similar to those that have followed every other frenzied introduction of a new technology, from railroads to automobiles to personal computers. It is a predictable cycle of growth, collapse, rebirth: An initial land grab starts as people rush to get in first and get big fast. Then, as often as not, the leaders collapse of their own unsupportable weight and others pick up the pieces and turn the good ideas into real businesses.

headline: Office Pool, 2002
summary: If you correctly predicted everything that happened in 2001, you belong in jail. Here is the office pool for the bounceback year; ''All'' and ''None'' are options. 1. Next nation to be hit for harboring terrorists is (a) Iraq; (b) Somalia; (c) Sudan; (d) North Korea; (e) Syria.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Is Raising Speculation In Hollywood
summary: A knock on the door from federal regulators usually sends shudders through any corporate suite. But when the Justice Department announced recently that it was investigating whether movie studios' efforts to offer films online to consumers at home were anticompetitive, Hollywood moguls barely seemed to look up from their wheat grass shakes. As multinational companies further consolidate and cross-promote their movie, television, Internet and music properties, it is becoming harder to say who is competing with whom and how it helps or hurts consumers, analysts say.

headline: ''Bons Mots? You Decide''
summary: THE economy may have slowed during 2001, but news in the business world didn't skip a beat. Among its highs and lows were many moments that were memorable for their importance, their humor or their sheer brazenness. Were you paying attention? Try this test. PART 1 Who spoke these words and about what? 1) ''It is not good news for America.'' 2) ''She has the full support of the board and will continue to lead the company through these challenging times.'' 3) ''The more I see about this deal, the less I like it.'' 4) ''I was smiling going in, because how often in your life do you and your company have an opportunity to make a difference?'' 5) ''I have no desire to be next at bat.'' 6) ''We are on the side of angels.'' 7) ''This is an industrial policy designed for shareholders of the winning companies.'' 8) ''It would be a good time for all parties to sit down together and see what kind of resolution can be worked out.'' 9) ''Today, America goes back to business.'' 10) ''What keeps me up at night is doing my own e-mail. headline: In the U.S., Interactive TV Still Awaits An Audience
summary: It has become a familiar refrain the last decade: this is the year for interactive television. It has not happened. But media and technology companies say 2002 may be it. Really. Cable companies, satellite television services, media conglomerates and Microsoft have all made interactive television a key part of their strategic visions. They are pouring billions into a flurry of deals.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Comcast Disruptions Reported
summary: About 10 percent of the 70,000 high-speed Internet customers on the Union, N.J., cable system of Comcast had service disruptions or other problems after Comcast tried to switch them to its high-speed Internet on Dec. 26. Most of those affected had received high-speed access from a Comcast partner, Excite@Home, which is in bankruptcy.

headline: State Attorney General Faults Sale of the Red Sox
summary: Major League Baseball in effect chose the winning bidder in the $660 million sale of the Boston Red Sox, Thomas Reilly, the Massachusetts attorney general, said yesterday, but he also said there was not much, if anything, he could do about it. ''What is clear is that Major League Baseball, and particularly the commissioner's office, played a major role in deciding who the next owner of the Red Sox would be,'' Reilly said. ''It's just another example of how they operate. It's a club. That's what it is. They get the benefit of the exemption from antitrust. When you see how they operate, it's not a pretty sight.''

headline: Comcast Copes With Internet Problems
summary: The Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it had ''for the most part'' solved technical problems that caused Internet and e-mail disruptions for about 7,000 New Jersey customers, though some customers say the company has played down the extent of the problems they have faced the last 10 days. The problems occurred as a result of Comcast's switching its high-speed Internet customers onto its own network, from a network operated by Excite@Home, which declared bankruptcy.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Argentina Is Preparing For Currency Devaluation With a substantial devaluation of their currency now certain, Argentines braced for the worst as President Eduardo Duhalde and his newly appointed cabinet discussed ways to cushion the blow and avoid a repetition of the riots and protests that toppled his predecessor. Economists and political leaders predict that the government will lower the exchange rate of the peso, which has been valued at one to one with the dollar for the last decade, by 30 percent to 40 percent. A formal announcement is expected as early as today. [Page A4.] Newmont Raises Bid for Normandy Newmont Mining of Denver sweetened its bid for Normandy Mining of Australia to $2.2 billion and appeared set to win the contest for the company after AngloGold of South Africa bowed out. [World Business, Section W.]

headline: AT&T Plans To Lay Off 5,000 Workers
summary: In a continued attempt to reduce its costs, AT&T announced yesterday that it planned to lay off 5,000 employees this year. The company said it would take a charge of about $1 billion, before taxes, in the fourth quarter of 2001 to cover the costs of these layoffs and the costs of having already dismissed 5,100 employees. About 2,000 of the employees laid off last year and this year work in New Jersey, where many of the company's operations are based, according to Eileen M. Connolly, a spokeswoman for AT&T.

headline: The Internet's Invisible Hand; At a Public Utility Serving the World, No One's Really in Charge. Does It Matter?
summary: NO one owns it. And no one in particular actually runs it. Yet more than half a billion people rely on it as they do a light switch. The Internet is a network whose many incarnations -- as obscure academic playpen, information superhighway, vast marketplace, sci-fi-inspired matrix -- have seen it through more than three decades of ceaseless evolution.

headline: I.S.P.'s Demise Brings A Bumpy Switchover
summary: I AM a freelance writer working from my house, and a high-speed Internet connection over a cable modem is my main link to the world. So word of financial problems last year at Excite@Home, my Internet service provider, worried me. If it died, would I still have my connection? Would I keep my e-mail address? Then, at a New Jersey diner, I overheard some people from Comcast, the cable company through which I had Excite@Home service, discussing the problem. When I asked, they reassured me there would be no interruption in service, come what may. Comcast, which then had three quarters of a million high-speed Internet customers (now 950,000), had been working on its own system since last January.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: OpenTV In Deal With AT&T
summary: OpenTV will offer interactive television services through a unit of AT&T that supplies digital cable channels to 275 cable operators across the country. The AT&T unit, Head end in the Sky, reaches six million digital cable customers in 2,000 communities. The cable operators will be able to offer OpenTV games, news, weather and horoscopes to customers who have Motorola DCT-2000 digital set-top boxes. Last year, AT&T announced a similar agreement with Liberate Technologies, an OpenTV rival. AT&T and Microsoft also have a longstanding relationship to develop interactive television services. Headend in the Sky is one of the AT&T cable businesses being acquired by Comcast. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

headline: Comcast's High-Speed Web Access, the Bored Game
summary: Comcast said that about 10 percent of the 71,000 customers in North Jersey that were moved onto the new network faced either intermittent, limited service failures or could not receive or send e-mail. ''These kinds of problems are very typical when you're launching something new,'' said Dave Watson, executive vice president of Comcast Cable, which is based in Philadelphia. Mr. Watson said the most seriously affected customers -- numbering fewer than 100 -- lost service for several days. The New York Times, Jan. 4, 2002 ''That's funny, because I know about 10.'' Dan Blatt, neighbor of mine The Game of High-Speed Internet Access by Comcast

headline: In AOL's Suit Against Microsoft, the Key Word Is Access
summary: The sweeping lawsuit filed on Tuesday by AOL Time Warner on behalf of its Netscape subsidiary against Microsoft reflects AOL's fears that Microsoft, if left unchecked, will use its software to control how AOL's media assets are packaged and delivered over the Internet. ''This lawsuit is about the future and how that future will play out,'' said Neil MacDonald, an analyst with the Gartner Group. ''AOL is trying to challenge the Microsoft threat here and now.''

headline: Others Are Frustrated With Comcast Connection
summary: To the Editor: I read ''Comcast's High-Speed Web Access, the Bored Game'' (Jersey, Jan. 20) with great amusement, and frustration. Since Dec. 27, I have had either intermittent or no service from Comcast. I've sent six e-mails to various customer support addresses and the only response I've gotten is that they are not going to answer because of the high volume of e-mail. They refer to a phone number that I have tried three or four times and gave up after 15 or 20 minutes of holding. Perhaps the most frustrating issue is that I cannot contact a live person to tell my problems to. I can't wait to get the month's bill; then they will listen when I refuse to pay for the lack of service. MARTIN MALKIN Cranford

headline: Others Are Frustrated With Comcast Connection
summary: To the Editor: Debra Galant's ''Comcast's High-Speed Web Access, the Bored Game'' mirrored my own experience in ''migrating'' to Comcast's new network: I was without Internet access from Dec. 27 to Jan. 14. After Comcast Cable's president predicted a ''seamless transition'' on Dec. 11 in a company press release, it's no surprise that Comcast won't acknowledge the true number of customers who were seriously affected by a poorly planned network conversion. If you can't control the damage, control the spin. DAVID B. BOELIO Maplewood

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AT&T and AOL are very different and yet very much alike.
summary: FROM the personality of their executives to the source of their power, AT&T and AOL Time Warner are very different sorts of companies. Yet as both titans reported quarterly financial results yesterday, it became clear that there were important similarities in the challenges they face and even in their responses to the obstacles. AT&T, the No. 1 long-distance communications company, and AOL Time Warner, the largest Internet and media company, each reported losing money in the fourth quarter of 2001. AT&T's loss was smaller than during the comparable period a year earlier. AOL's was bigger. By AOL's preferred measure of earnings, which excludes many charges, the company's results matched analysts' expectations. By a similar measure, AT&T's results barely beat expectations.

headline: In the Region/New Jersey; Realty Firms Offer Help in Settling in a New Home
summary: ON the list of traumatic experiences life has to offer, moving to a new home has been regularly ranked near the top, not far behind the death of a loved one, divorce and losing a job. Real estate agencies are expending extra effort these days to reduce the stress. ''We don't want our company to be associated in people's minds with an experience that produces any nightmares,'' said Fred Watkins, president of Weichert Realtors' financial services group. Weichert has begun offering mortgage clients what it calls Gold Service to smooth transitions -- including not only the usual service discounts, but actual help getting things done.

headline: Satellite Agreement For Yankees Games
summary: The YES Network made its first deal yesterday to guarantee that viewers can see Yankees games, but it was not with local cable companies like Time Warner, Cablevision or Comcast. Instead, it was a satellite agreement with DirecTV.

headline: New-School Dinner Raises $1.3 Million
summary: Demonstrating some of his legendary drawing power, BOB KERREY, below, president of New School University and former senator from Nebraska, attracted a host of luminaries to the university's annual La Guardia Award benefit dinner last week, which raised nearly $1.3 million for scholarships and to support the university's Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy. Benefit chairmen included PETE PETERSON, chairman of the Blackstone Group; BRIAN ROBERTS, president of Comcast Inc.; and JOHN L. TISHMAN, chairman of Tishman Realty and Construction and chairman of the university's board. GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI delivered the keynote address. The 2002 Fiorello H. La Guardia award was given to FELIX G. ROHATYN, the former United States ambassador to France. Mr. Royatyn took the lead in helping to bail New York City out of its mid-1970's financial crisis. Karen W. Arenson

headline: Residential Real Estate; Residence Hall and Academic Center for Columbia
summary: With a new residence hall for Columbia University Law School to go up this year and plans for a new academic center for the university's School of Social Work in their final stages, the landscape of 121st and 122nd Streets between Amsterdam Avenue and Morningside Drive is about to undergo a marked transformation. Construction is to begin this month on Lenfest Hall, a 16-story apartment building at 425 West 121st Street meant primarily for graduate law students. The site is now a parking lot.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: An Effort to Tighten Rules In Wake of Enron's Collapse Regulators, legislators and the chief accounting rule maker proposed changes in the way companies do business and report their finances, including closing the loophole that Enron used to hide hundreds of millions of dollars of debt and inflate its profits. The board that sets accounting rules and the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated that they intended to move far more rapidly than they have in the past. [Page A1.]

headline: Comcast Says It Will Stop Storing Data On Customers
summary: Facing criticism from a member of Congress and privacy advocacy groups, the Comcast Corporation said today that it would no longer store data that would enable it to track individual subscribers' Internet surfing habits. Comcast, which provides high-speed Internet access through cable modems to 948,000 customers, said it changed the policy to reassure customers it would not track their individual movements on the Internet. But the company said that even before it changed the policy, it had not tracked individuals' behavior, but rather, had sought to gather aggregate data on the habits of its users.

headline: Another Snag For Comcast As Its E-Mail Goes Awry
summary: Hitting yet another snag in its nascent Internet service, the Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it was scrambling to repair an e-mail failure that had left as many as 300,000 customers unable to receive messages. Starting at 10 p.m. Wednesday, customers were able to receive e-mail messages intermittently, but by noon yesterday, they were unable to receive them at all, said Dave Watson, executive vice president for marketing at Comcast. Mr. Watson said the company hoped to restore full e-mail service by late last night, but, if not, would ''work around the clock'' to do so.

headline: Disney's Chief Seems Cool on a Hot Seat
summary: When Michael D. Eisner, the longtime chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, takes the stage at the company's annual shareholder meeting in Hartford, Conn., on Tuesday, he is going to have a lot of explaining to do. Ratings have plummeted 21 percent this season among total viewers at the ABC television network, putting ABC in third place. ABC Entertainment has replaced a handful of senior executives in recent years. And Disney's stock price has underperformed not only the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the last five years but also the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq.

headline: Cablevision Is Holding Off on Carrying YES
summary: AOL Time Warner and Comcast are expected to announce next week that they will carry the fledgling YES network -- which will feature 130 Yankee games -- as a basic service on its cable systems. Cablevision remains a holdout because it views YES as too expensive. The deals with AOL Time Warner and Comcast will give YES an estimated 3.5 million subscribers in the market, but Cablevision's position means the network will most likely be seen in a modest percentage of its 2.9 million cable homes in the region.

headline: APPELLATE COURT EASES LIMITATIONS FOR MEDIA GIANTS
summary: A federal appeals court handed a huge victory to the nation's largest television networks and cable operators today, ruling that the government had to reconsider sharp limits on the number of stations a network can own and striking down the regulation that had restricted cable operators from owning television stations. Unless overturned on appeal the ruling would remove significant impediments that have prevented companies like AOL Time Warner, a big cable operator, from merging with broadcast networks that own TV stations. It would also permit big broadcast networks like Viacom's CBS and the News Corporation's Fox, which have bumped against the station-ownership limits, to continue buying stations, unimpeded. [Page C1.]

headline: Court Ruling May Change Landscape For Media
summary: Investment bankers, start your engines. That was essentially the message to Wall Street and the media industry yesterday as a federal appeals court in Washington unleashed what is expected to be a major wave of deal making, with the titans of the television business snapping up their smaller brethren.

headline: Are Investors Too Worried About Cable?
summary: THERE are times when investors grow so worried about what might go wrong that they overestimate the chance that disaster will happen. Eleven years ago, during the last recession, investor fears crystalized around banks. After a wave of bank failures, it was clear that many banks had abused accounting rules to make themselves look healthier than they were. Many banks traded as if failure was a real possibility. Some did fail, but most did not. It was a great time to buy a portfolio of bank stocks.

headline: AT&T Moves Its President Closer to the Top Position
summary: By all appearances, David W. Dorman would have to do something shocking to avoid becoming AT&T's next chief executive. That became clear yesterday as AT&T named Mr. Dorman, the company's president, to the board. It has been clear for at least a year that Mr. Dorman was the favorite to become the chief executive once the company sold or spun off its cable television operation. With yesterday's announcement, the favorite became all but a shoo-in.

headline: Time Warner Adds YES for Subscribers
summary: Time Warner Cable announced yesterday that it would add the new YES Network to its metropolitan-area systems, which serve about three million subscribers. Subscribers outside New York City will be able to see YES as a basic cable channel on a 24-hour basis. In New York City, about 400,000 subscribers with the digital upgrade to Time Warner's standard basic tier will get YES as a stand-alone channel, enabling them to see 130 Yankees games, 75 Nets games, and all other programming.

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for JORDAN E. ROHAN; A Court Reshuffles the Television Deck
summary: LAST week, a federal appeals court in Washington handed down a set of decisions that could reshape the nation's media landscape. The court threw out rules that had prevented companies from owning a cable television system and a local broadcast television station in the same market. It also cast into serious doubt rules that prevent a single company from owning broadcast television stations that reach more than 35 percent of the nation's households with television. In response to the ruling, the Federal Communications Commission is expected either to raise the cap, perhaps to 50 percent, or to eliminate it.

headline: Sheldon B. Satin, 69, Cable TV Consultant
summary: Sheldon B. Satin, who helped make cable television popular by consulting in marketing and customer service, died Friday in Stamford, Conn. He was 69 and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y. The cause was a brain tumor, his wife, Joan Throckmorton, said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Fate of Letterman Unclear; News Seen at Risk on ABC The president of ABC News, David Westin, told his staff that his bosses had not told him that ABC wanted to remove his most prestigious program, ''Nightline,'' to make room for David Letterman. The fate of Mr. Letterman's show, which ABC is trying to take from CBS, remained unclear. Still, that ABC would consider removing ''Nightline'' was taken as an indication in the news division that the network's parent, Walt Disney, would not hesitate to cut news to improve its balance sheet. [Page A1.]

headline: Comcast Says Its Transition To Internet Network Is Done
summary: The Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its transition of thousand of clients to its own high-speed Internet network and e-mail system -- a months-long process that had been fraught with technical problems and that presented newfound e-mail delays in the last several days. Dave Watson, vice president for marketing at Comcast, a Philadelphia-based cable operator that provides Internet access over cable modems, said that some customers were experiencing a ''small'' delay in receiving e-mail. But some customers, who said the delays were more substantial than the company indicated, said they had not been able to receive e-mail at all, or, in some cases, send it.

headline: In Fight With Cablevision, YES Network Urges Yankees Fans to Make Switch
summary: Cablevision's refusal to carry the YES Network, the new cable home of the Yankees, as a basic service is fueling a campaign to persuade Cablevision's customers to switch to satellite service. The network makes its premiere March 19 and the first regular-season Yankees game is April 1.

headline: Comcast Cable To Carry YES
summary: Comcast Cable yesterday became the second major cable systems owner in the New York metropolitan area to agree to carry the YES Network, the new home of the Yankees. Comcast, with 900,000 subscribers in New Jersey and Connecticut, joins Time Warner Cable, which made its agreement with YES last month. Both will carry YES on basic cable.

headline: Pressure Increases on Cablevision to Carry YES
summary: If a feud between Cablevision and the YES Network, the Yankees' new television channel, is not resolved, three million households will not be able to watch Yankees games on local cable when the season starts on April 1. YES, which will carry 130 Yankees games, wants to be carried on Cablevision's systems as a basic offering, like Lifetime or A&E. But Cablevision has refused, insisting that the fee for YES is too high and that the channel belongs on a premium tier, where only the customers who want it can buy it, the same way they would subscribe to HBO.

headline: Eye on Profits, Murdoch Focuses on Details
summary: Rupert Murdoch, whose name is virtually synonymous with that of the company he runs, the News Corporation, is known in the media world as a man of big ideas. Two decades ago, he reached beyond his chain of Australian newspapers to buy The Times of London and soon took on Britain's powerful labor unions, moving the paper to profitability. Later in the 1980's, he successfully created the Fox network, the United States' first new commercial broadcast network since the early days of television.

headline: YES Disputes Claims in Cablevision Ad
summary: The chief executive of the YES Network yesterday labeled as fraudulent a new television commercial describing the 32 Yankee games that Cablevision customers will be able to watch in the absence of the 130 to be televised by YES. Cablevision refuses to pay YES a monthly fee of $2 a subscriber to carry the channel as a basic network. It wants to place it on a premium tier. Time Warner, Comcast, RCN and DirecTV have all agreed to YES's terms. If there is no deal, Cablevision's three million subscribers will not see some or all of YES's 130 Yankees games.

headline: Chase's Early Dalliances With Global Crossing
summary: From the beginning it was a seductive relationship, with mutual needs and desires overwhelming the warnings to proceed cautiously. Now one of the parties, Global Crossing, is said to owe about $95 million to the other, J. P. Morgan Chase, which has little chance of recovering more than pennies on the dollar. Among the investment banks that did business with Global Crossing, J. P. Morgan Chase in particular saw Global Crossing as the main chance -- a way to make its mark in telecommunications, a red-hot field for investment bankers in the late 90's.

headline: Now on YES, It's Dynasty, For Those Not in the Dark
summary: For sports fans who believe the Yankees have too many World Series titles, too many Hall of Fame players, too loud an owner and too much cash, the new YES Network is the newest symbol of the team's expanding power. When YES makes its debut at noon today with a half-hour introductory show (a Yankees exhibition game against the Reds will be broadcast at 7 p.m.), viewers will bear witness to a cable channel defined by rampant pinstripism -- the culmination of nearly 30 years of Yankees ownership by George M. Steinbrenner 3rd.

headline: Stay Tuned: Yankees Coverage Still Up in Air
summary: FOR New York Yankees fans, watching cable television, and more specifically, Cablevision's Madison Square Garden Network, was how they followed their team to four World Series championships and five American League championships over the past six years. Now, however, with the start of a new baseball season fast approaching, many Yankees fans in southwestern Connecticut suddenly find themselves preparing, at least temporarily, for a return to the days when they relied on radio and newspapers rather than television to keep tabs on their heroes.

headline: Cablevision Adds Free Coverage
summary: Cablevision announced yesterday that subscribers in the metropolitan area who have MSG Network or Fox Sports New York will receive the one they do not have for free this year. The decision was made necessary when Cablevision shifted 50 of 100 Mets games from FSNY to MSG to partly make up for the loss of Yankees games to the new YES Network. Having paid a fee to watch the Mets on FSNY, subscribers were concerned that they would have to pay another one to get MSG.

headline: YES Says No to Cablevision Proposal
summary: Cablevision, which has resisted carrying the Yankees' new cable channel as part of its basic package, proposed a compromise of sorts yesterday. Cablevision said it would carry the Yankees' channel, the YES Network, on its systems but would allow YES to set the price and keep all the revenues. YES rejected the idea, labeling it undemocratic and unfair.

headline: The True Madness Concerns the Money
summary: The talk from CBS at the N.C.A.A. men's tournament is, predictably, about games and players. So much time is spent on Juan Dixon, Tom Coverdale, Drew Gooden and the Final Four matchups that no one utters a word on the air about what the network pays for the 10-day event, which ends Monday night. The cost is $258 million this year, more than any network pays annually for a half-season of Nascar.

headline: Market Place; Will Ma Bell Be Taken Over By Offspring?
summary: Will AT&T stand alone as a telecommunications company? Many industry executives say they believe that by the middle of next year, a big local phone company like SBC Communications or BellSouth will try to acquire what remains of AT&T.

headline: Cablevision Audience Misses Opener on YES
summary: The YES Network came to regular-season life in the New York market yesterday for about five million cable and satellite households. But for three million Cablevision subscribers, YES was merely a name, not a reality, as it could continue to be for 129 more Yankees telecasts on YES this season unless dÃ©tente is achieved.

headline: Are 25 Cable Systems Wrong?
summary: The YES Network's ambition for its 130 Yankees games to be seen by the entire New York market has been dashed by Cablevision's refusal to carry it as a basic channel. Yet 25 other cable operators, including Time Warner and Comcast, have agreed to YES's terms. Why did they say yes and why is Cablevision saying no? To Leo Hindery Jr., the chairman of YES, the answer is simple: ''It's the Yankees, fairly priced and fairly packaged.''

headline: Why Cablevision and YES Are So Rigid
summary: If you are a Yankees fan and get your cable TV through Cablevision, you are feeling lost these days, like Ed Norton without his vest or Puff Daddy without his Diddy. You could not watch the opening game Monday afternoon in Baltimore or last night's game, for that matter, because of a dispute that is keeping the YES Network, newly created by the Yankees, off Cablevision's systems. YES is carrying 130 games this season.

headline: Cable Standoff Stretches Into Season, to Yankee Fans' Frustration
summary: Rebecca Stonefield is among the thousands of Yankees fans in the New York region who are sick and tired of the dispute that is keeping her baseball team off cable networks in her neighborhood. She does not care who is right in the dispute between the cable television company and the entertainment network that carries the Yankees. She does not care which one of them stands to lose money. And if it comes to it, she will pay more.

headline: Winning Games But Not Hearts
summary: JOE ENTENA had driven from Bloomfield, and his friend Alisa Disabunjong made a slightly shorter drive from Bogota. They arrived at the Continental Airlines Arena more than an hour early, but it was worth waiting around to get a chance to stand courtside to see their favorite player before a recent New Jersey Nets game. ''Yeah, the reason why we're here is No. 15,'' Entena said, pointing to the purple jerseys, displaying that No. 15, that he and Disanbunjong were wearing. Down the row of fans, at least a half-dozen others wore the same kind of jersey, with the same number. The problem, at least for the Nets, was that purple-jerseyed No. 15 is worn by Vince Carter, a star for the visiting Toronto Raptors, who, having grown up in Florida and played college ball for the University of North Carolina, does not have even a tenuous New Jersey connection.

headline: New Economy; Cable Is Offering More Viewing On Demand
summary: The optimists have long said that video on demand is the future of television. To which the pessimists have retorted: And it always will be. Now, though, television seems to be finally catching up with its future, at least in terms of the technology. Still unclear is whether enough content and revenue will materialize to make video on demand more than a passing fad.

headline: Sports of The Times; Don't Feud, George; Take the High Ground
summary: DEAR GEORGE: Time to cut the commercials and the rest of the smear campaign. It is starting to sound self-righteous and it isn't working either. Dolan, the Cable Guy, has not budged in his refusal to accept your prized Yankees telecasts for his basic Cablevision packages. The season is seven games old, the divisional race may already be over and the Cablevision subscribers who have not ordered the dish or cannot order the dish because they are apartment dwellers have been exposed to exactly eight and a half innings against the quasi-major league outfit from Tampa Bay. Day by day, while your Yankees are winning, your signal-shorn fans are losing, and what, exactly, are you doing about it besides spending a small fortune on those tacky I-want-my-Yankees man-in-the-street spots that have been flooding the airwaves?

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AT&T, Hardly a Penny Stock, Plans 1-for-5 Reverse Stock Split
summary: Is it conceivable that shares of AT&T, one of the world's signature corporations, might trade for less than $5? Not to AT&T's board apparently. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, AT&T said it planned to ask shareholders to approve a 1-for-5 reverse stock split. The move would have no substantive effect on AT&T's operations or finances. Instead, it is being proposed for its supposed psychological effect on investors, according to people close to AT&T.

headline: Cox Empire Seeks Growth (on Its Own Terms)
summary: SOME years ago, James Cox Kennedy, the chairman of Cox Enterprises, was flying to Hawaii with his mother and some friends. Unhappy that she was smoking, Mr. Kennedy admonished her to stop. When she paid no heed, he tried leverage. ''It's a company plane,'' he warned. ''It's my company,'' Barbara Cox Anthony, now 79, shot back.

headline: How Does AOL Fit in the Grand Plan Now?
summary: STEPHEN M. CASE, Richard D. Parsons and Robert W. Pittman, the men at the helm of AOL Time Warner, do not yet agree on just how the America Online Internet service -- one of the company's biggest divisions -- should evolve or on just how quickly it can grow over the next few years. As Mr. Parsons, a renowned corporate diplomat, prepares to take over as AOL Time Warner's chief executive next month, forging that consensus is his most important challenge, and a vital one for the company, the world's largest media conglomerate. America Online's slowing growth over the last year and its failure to meet Wall Street expectations have been a drag on the company's shares. And the absence of a unified vision of America Online's future -- of just how the Internet can work with old media like movies to deliver vast new profits, as promised -- is raising questions anew about the wisdom of the merger that created the company two years ago, at the peak of the Internet bubble.

headline: I Take It Back: Cable Glitch Was My Fault
summary: I THOUGHT I had my cable company, Comcast, dead to rights. In December, when Comcast was switching its high-speed Internet customers from Excite@Home's cable-modem service to its own, I lost access to my favorite online news sources. When I tried browsing Web addresses like www.nytimes.com, I got only error messages. And for months I moaned and raged at Comcast tech support, to no avail. But with computers, things are seldom what they seem.

headline: AT&T Lost Almost $1 Billion, But There Were Bright Spots
summary: AT&T, the nation's No. 1 long-distance communications and cable television company, said yesterday that it lost almost $1 billion in the first quarter while its revenue shrank more than 11 percent, the fifth consecutive quarterly decline. Although those were hardly rosy results, in light of the carnage in the telecommunications industry recently, it was not such a poor performance. The company's shares fell 10 cents, to $13.75.

headline: YES-Cablevision War Has a Winner: DirecTV
summary: The great unknown in the absence of the YES Network from Cablevision's local systems is how many of its three million subscribers have fled to DirecTV's satellite service to watch Yankees games. DirecTV will not divulge the figure other than to say its activation rate -- new subscribers taking the service -- increased 100 percent from March to April, after rising some 20 percent from February to March.

headline: Feathered Creatures in Spring
summary: No, it's not January. And it's the New Jersey side of the Delaware. But the Mummers, those befeathered, banjo strumming staples of New Year's Day in Philadelphia, will strut just across the Delaware River in Gloucester City starting at 2 this afternoon.

headline: COMCAST REPORTS $88.9 MILLION LOSS IN FIRST QUARTER
summary: Comcast, the cable television operator planning to buy AT&T's cable unit, said yesterday that it had a first-quarter loss of $88.9 million on investments and the expense of buying and upgrading systems for digital TV and Internet services. Sales rose 20 percent, to $2.67 billion, more than analysts had expected. Cable revenue rose 12 percent. Profit, excluding items like depreciation and interest, rose 27 percent, to $808.2 million, or 85 cents a share.

headline: A Conversation With the Next Mogul of Cable TV
summary: Brian L. Roberts may be the least probable mogul. He wears a power suit, but is unprepossessing. He was born into wealth, but does not seem entitled. The stock of his company, Comcast, is down sharply this year. Yet Comcast, where Mr. Roberts, 42, is the president, is poised to become the nation's biggest cable television company and one of the world's most powerful media companies -- assuming regulators approve its $47 billion stock deal for AT&T's cable business later this year.

headline: Chief-to-Be Says AOL Has One Problem Area
summary: Richard D. Parsons, who will become AOL Time Warner's chief executive later this month, said today that the company still faced significant problems and still had to answer questions about its strategic direction. But he vigorously defended the overall vision for AOL Time Warner, the world's biggest media company, and said there were no plans to split the company. ''We're the No. 1 movie company, the No. 1 online company, the No. 1 premium cable network company, the No. 1 cable network company, No. 2 cable company, No. 2 music company,'' he said here in a panel discussion at the cable television industry's annual convention. ''What am I missing?

headline: Adelphia to Put Some Cable Systems Up for Sale
summary: Adelphia Communications said yesterday that it was putting several of its cable systems on the market in an effort to raise cash. The company is offering its Southern California system, with more than 1.2 million subscribers, as well as systems in Florida (750,000 subscribers), Virginia (575,000) and the Carolinas and Georgia (a total of 225,000 subscribers).

headline: Investing; Where Telecom Bargain Hunters Turn
summary: IT has been two months since Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon Communications, mused at an investment conference that his company might bid for WorldCom ''for the fun of it'' if the stock price of that long-distance and Internet carrier continued falling. Since then, WorldCom's shares have dropped 80 percent, to $1.58 on Friday. But as Mr. Seidenberg wryly suggested, conditions in the communications sector are so tough that Verizon has no real interest in WorldCom at any price. Verizon, along with rivals like SBC Communications, BellSouth and Deutsche Telekom, all have plenty of their own problems without taking on WorldCom's, which include gigantic debt and an accounting investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: New Economy; 'Interactive' isn't a word cable customers are interested in.
summary: IF anyone has deserved to be called Mr. Interactive Television in recent years, it has probably been Mitchell E. Kertzman, chief executive of Liberate Technologies. With almost $90 million in revenue over its last four quarters, Liberate is a leading independent developer of software for cable television set-top boxes that allow viewers to use two-way services. Liberate counts just about every major cable television company in the world among its clients. Mr. Kertzman has been so bullish about interactive television that last year he even tried, without success, to persuade Microsoft to sell its interactive television business to Liberate.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Sets Separate Votes On Cable Deal
summary: AT&T said its shareholders would vote separately on the sale of its broadband unit to Comcast and the proposed management structure for the company that will be created by the merger, which has been tentatively set by the AT&T board and Comcast officials. For the agreement to be completed, AT&T officials said, shareholders must approve both measures at the company's annual meeting in Charleston, S.C. in July. The combined company, to be called the AT&T Comcast Corporation, will be the nation's largest cable television company. Shareholders of Comcast, based in Philadelphia, are scheduled to vote on the $72 billion deal in June. AT&T officials said allowing shareholders to vote on both matters will expedite the process. The agreement requires antitrust clearance from the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: Cable Industry Plays Catch-Up
summary: ANYONE who believes that the survivors of a consolidating industry will always succeed in the stock market should look at the cable television business. Seven cable companies control more than 85 percent of the market. Shares of the five companies that trade as independent entities -- Comcast, Cablevision Systems, Cox Communications, Adelphia Communications and Charter Communications -- are down 46 percent, on average, this year. AT&T and AOL Time Warner, the two biggest operators, haven't done well either.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Debate Grows Over Links In Government to Business Disputes over contacts between corporations and senior government officials who regulate them have become an almost daily ritual of Washington life. While the debate is not new, it has heated up. Senate Democrats have become emboldened in challenging an administration with strong pro-business leanings. The issue has also underscored the differences in disclosure among executive departments and independent agencies. [Page C5.]

headline: AT&T's Financial Chief to Quit After Cable TV Sale
summary: AT&T announced yesterday that Charles H. Noski, its widely respected No. 2 executive, would leave the company after it completes the sale of its cable television operations to the Comcast Corporation, expected late this year. Mr. Noski's planned departure was not surprising but does raise the question of what he may do next. AT&T's shares barely budged on the news, rising 19 cents, to $13.14.

headline: Why Big Ideas Often Fall Flat
summary: IN the spring of 2000, I interviewed Richard A. McGinn, then the chief executive of Lucent Technologies. Lucent had missed one quarterly earnings estimate in January, so I asked Mr. McGinn whether that was the beginning of a long-term problem or a one-time event. He assured me that Lucent was back on a positive earnings path and wowed me with all the technological marvels in Bell Labs, which Lucent owns. I accepted Mr. McGinn's version for my article, for U.S. News & World Report. Within months, Lucent missed its earnings target again. Then it happened again. By year's end, Mr. McGinn was out of a job.

headline: Industry Allies Seek to Limit Microsoft Drive Into New Fields
summary: The organization, the Liberty Alliance, was off to a good start, but its image was a bit of a problem. At a meeting last January in Orlando, some members of the alliance, which includes American Express, General Motors and United Airlines, chided the representative from Sun Microsystems for statements portraying the Liberty Alliance as an anti-Microsoft initiative. ''Would any of you be here if it wasn't for Microsoft?'' Jonathan I. Schwartz, the Sun executive, asked in reply.

headline: U.S. Soccer: Sport of 70's, 80's and 90's Still Waits
summary: True, none of the American players are married to a Spice Girl, as is England's top star. President Bush did not invite the national team over for a send-off luncheon, as did Italy's prime minister. The loss of a starting midfielder to injury did not send the country into a panic attack. And the American coach has no personal biographer, as does his counterpart in China. This lack of national passion has prompted the same question to be asked repeatedly and skeptically for decades: When is soccer going to make it in the United States?

headline: Bankruptcy Of a Division May Signal Adelphia's Fall
summary: Complications mounted yesterday for the embattled cable company Adelphia Communications, as one of its units filed for bankruptcy protection, two newly appointed Adelphia directors resigned and the company filed documents showing it had overstated revenue and cash flow for the last two years. The Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, by Adelphia's Century Communications unit, was widely seen as a precursor to a bankruptcy filing within days by Adelphia itself. Adelphia is in default on $7 billion in loans, and its shares have been delisted by the Nasdaq stock market.

headline: AMR EXECUTIVE TO BECOME CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER AT AT&T
summary: The AT&T Corporation named Thomas W. Horton, the chief financial officer of the AMR Corporation, senior executive vice president and chief financial officer yesterday. Mr. Horton, 41, succeeds Charles H. Noski as chief financial officer. Mr. Noski was named AT&T's vice chairman in February, although in May, he announced his intention to leave the company when its cable unit merges with Comcast. Mr. Noski will continue as vice chairman through the closing of the merger, which is expected by the end of the year. Separately, AMR named Jeffrey C. Campbell, 41, chief financial officer and senior vice president for finance, replacing Mr. Horton.

headline: Partner Takes Cable Systems, 2 Million Users From AOL
summary: AOL Time Warner, the world's biggest media company, said yesterday that it had lost control of cable television systems serving more than two million customers. The development was a setback for AOL, which is the No. 2 cable television operator in the United States. It followed three months of negotiations in which AOL had sought unsuccessfully to retain the systems, which it controlled through a partnership with Advance/Newhouse Communications.

headline: Trying to Catch WorldCom's Mirage
summary: ON Dec. 6, 1999, AT&T replaced the chief of its huge business services division, Michael G. Keith, after barely nine months on the job. To the outside world, it appeared that C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman and chief executive, had moved Mr. Keith to the company's wireless unit simply because he was not getting the job done. Now some people close to AT&T say Mr. Keith was actually transferred mostly because his division could not match the reported profit margins of its biggest competitor, WorldCom.

headline: New Economy; Scandals appall some longtime corporate chiefs.
summary: WHEN President Bush pledged last week to ''hold people accountable'' in the WorldCom bookkeeping scandal, he picked an apt phrase. Whatever the reasons Mr. Bush waited for WorldCom to blow up before finally voicing outrage, it's reasonable to demand accountability for the accounting crisis in corporate America. The president isn't alone in his disgust. The stream of scandals -- WorldCom, Global Crossing, Enron, and on and on -- appalls some longtime corporate leaders, who recall an era before the Internet stock bubble brought its social pathology.

headline: AOL Time Warner Under More Pressure
summary: The efforts of AOL Time Warner's chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, to refurbish his company's battered credibility on Wall Street became a lot more difficult yesterday when its rival Vivendi Universal showed signs of falling apart. ''This is calling into question all of the merger and acquisition activity that has happened in media in the last decade,'' said Paul Kim, analyst at Kaufman Brothers. ''People are asking, do these conglomerate structures create any value, or do they blur visibility and make it hard for investors to figure out what is really going on in the company?''

headline: N.B.A. and AOL Drop Plan For an All-Sports Network
summary: The National Basketball Association has decided not to start an all-sports network with AOL Time Warner. Instead, AOL Time Warner will pay $45 million for a 10 percent stake in NBA TV, the league's existing digital cable channel. NBA TV will carry 98 regular-season games, or about four a week, the same number as the proposed network would have carried.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
summary: Bush Used Insider Benefits That He Now Wants to Ban President Bush has called for an end to some of the very insider transactions that he used as a director of Harken Energy in the late 1980's. Mr. Bush received two low-interest loans and then benefited from the company's relaxation of the terms of one loan. On Tuesday, he challenged directors to ''put an end to all company loans to corporate officers.'' Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director, discounted suggestions that Mr. Bush was being hypocritical in calling for an end to loans of a kind he once received. Mr. Bartlett said that while such loans had been properly used in the past, they had recently been abused. [Page A1.]

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; After some hostility, AT&T shareholders approve a breakup.
summary: AT&T shareholders gave their approval yesterday to the breakup of what is left of the company into three pieces. But one part of that breakup may never happen. In scheduling the shareholder vote on the breakup in Charleston, S.C., from which the first shots were fired in a previous unsuccessful breakup -- also known as the Civil War -- AT&T was clearly not too worried about historical precedents of long ago.

headline: 'Retreat' Seems to Fit Mood Of Media's Big Gathering
summary: Dozens of private jets filled the tarmac at the tiny airport in nearby Hailey, Idaho, this week as top communications industry executives gathered for golf, river rafting and outdoor ice skating here at the annual retreat held by the investment banker Herbert Allen, a summer camp for media moguls. But with many media company stocks trading near lows for the year, the mood this year was more chastened and anxious than during the merger-minded gatherings of years past. Conversation centered on the cash squeeze gripping the media industry and the new scrutiny of its accounting techniques.

headline: AT&T Says Its President Will Take Over Top Spot
summary: AT&T announced yesterday that David W. Dorman, its president, would succeed C. Michael Armstrong as chairman and chief executive beginning next year. Mr. Dorman, an executive with extensive experience in the telecommunications industry, was widely expected to be named to the top job at AT&T, a company that has changed markedly since it spun off its wireless operation and agreed to sell its cable television operations to Comcast.

headline: The Stairmaster of Mergers
summary: EVEN before it bought Time Warner two years ago, America Online had ambition to spare -- a sense that history, technology and markets were all going its way. It was a corporate attitude that often bordered on arrogance. The goal was nothing less than to ''establish AOL as the most valuable and respected company,'' declared Stephen M. Case, then chairman of America Online, in 1999. ''We won't settle for just one of them.''

headline: AT&T, Writing Down Cable Assets, Posts Big Loss
summary: AT&T announced quarterly financial results yesterday that it said modestly exceeded analysts' expectations, amid signs that the trends that have devastated parts of its business, if not getting better, are at least not growing worse. Both AT&T's consumer and business-services operations are still shrinking because of continued weakness in the company's core long-distance telephone market. Many consumers and companies are turning to cellphones and e-mail as alternatives to wired telephones. Those trends continue, but AT&T said yesterday that at least the pace of deterioration in its core operations was no longer accelerating.

headline: Paul Allen May Try to Raise Cable TV Stake
summary: Paul G. Allen, the chairman of Charter Communications, is considering several steps to significantly increase his stake in the company and perhaps even take it private, according to executives briefed on the deliberations. The collapse in the stock price of Charter, the nation's No. 4 cable-television company with about 6.8 million customers, may have created an opportunity for Mr. Allen, a billionaire who co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates in the mid-1970's. The company's shares, after ending this year's first trading day at $16.59, closed on Friday at $2.64, making Charter's market value about $780 million.

headline: AT&T and AOL Are Said to Seek Delay in Evaluation of Joint Entertainment Unit
summary: Locked in talks over the fate of their joint venture of Time Warner Entertainment, AT&T and AOL Time Warner agreed yesterday to ask Bank of America to withhold its opinion on how much AT&T's stake is worth, according to executives close to the companies. The request was a sign that the companies expect to reach a settlement within weeks on dissolving the venture. While AOL has tried to persuade AT&T to swap its 27.3 percent of Time Warner Entertainment for a stake in a newly created Time Warner Cable operation, AT&T wants at least $1 billion in cash and billions of dollars in stock in the parent AOL Time Warner in addition to a stake in the cable subsidiary, according to people close to the negotiations.

headline: U.S. Initiates Investigation Of Accounting At AOL Unit
summary: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that the Justice Department had begun an investigation into accounting practices at its AOL division, after the initiation last week of an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission. AOL Time Warner reiterated yesterday that its outside auditors, Ernst & Young, had repeatedly certified its books.
